--- title: "Variance of grouped data" image: "/images/biostats.jpg" date: "2024-11-10" format: html: fig-align: center page-layout: article toc: true toc-depth: 5 toc-expand: true lightbox: false crossref: custom: - kind: float reference-prefix: "Example M.10." key: tabset space-before-numbering: false editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Background - Assume that we grouped the variable `mpg` into the following class intervals: | Class Interval $(j)$ | $n_j$ | $\bar{x}_j$ | $s_j^2$ | |:--------------------:|:-----:|:-----------:|:-------:| | $[10,15]$ | $6$ | $13.017$ | $4.438$ | | $(15,20]$ | $12$ | $17.342$ | $2.812$ | | $(20,25]$ | $8$ | $22.038$ | $1.429$ | | $(25,30]$ | $2$ | $26.650$ | $0.845$ | | $(30,35]$ | $4$ | $31.775$ | $2.896$ | - Let's try to estimate the total variance of the variable `mpg` $(s^2 = 36.324)$ using the variance of the grouped data. - The variance of the grouped data is given by: $$ s^2_b = \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} \displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{k} n_j \cdot (\bar{x}_j - \bar{x})^2 $$ - This is known as the `variance between different classes` or `between-group variance`, which indicates the variability of the group (i.e., class) means $x_j$, weighted by the size of each group $n_j$, around the overall mean $\bar{x} = 20.090$. - In this case, $$ s^2_b = \frac{1}{32} [6 \times (13.017 - 20.090)^2 + 12 \times (17.342 - 20.090)^2\ + $$ $$ 8 \times (22.038 - 20.090)^2 + 2 \times (26.650 - 20.090)^2\ + $$ $$ 4 \times (31.775 - 20.090)^2 = 32.9176 $$ - As we can see, the between-group variance $(32.9176)$ underestimates the total variance $(36.324)$. - This happens because we ignored the `variance within each class` or `within-group variance`, which measures the variability of the observations within each group. - The within-group variance is given by: $$ s^2_w = \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} \displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{k} (n_j - 1) \cdot s_j^2 $$ ## References - Chen, Y. (2017). Lecture 7: Density Estimation. University of Washington. Retrieved October 05, 2024, from https://faculty.washington.edu/yenchic/17Sp_403/Lec7-density.pdf - Daniel, W. W. and Cross, C. L. (2013). Biostatistics: A Foundation for Analysis in the Health Sciences, Tenth edition. Wiley - Heumann, C., Schomaker, M., and Shalabh (2022).
